results.title: Watch Graham Bell go heli skiing in the Italian Alps
results.body:
Ski Sunday presenter Graham Bell, and ex-Olympic downhill ski racer, knows a great run when he skis one.

That's why Telegraph Ski and Snowboard asked him to pick stand out runs from around the world and talk us down each one - all the while filming himself navigating them on skis.

From much-loved pistes to infamous off-piste routes, Bell selected only the finest runs. So far he's tackled a number of French favourites including the Grand Couloir run in Courchevel and the Face de Bellevarde (La Face) black run in Val d'Isère as well as Austria's steepest piste the Harakiri, the off-piste Valluga run in St Anton and of the most scenic runs in the Alps, the Lagazuoi in Cortina d'Ampezzo.

In an adventurous twist to his search for the world's best ski runs Graham heads to Alagna, Italy, for a heli skiing trip with his trusty camera for company.

Graham is part of a group of 16 who take a helicopter ride up to the Piramide Vincent peak that rises to 4,215m. It's the highest point in the Monte Rosa ski area, which is made up of the three resorts Alagna, Champoluc and Gressoney.

After a short flight the group have a wide open off-piste run all to themselves from the summit, with crystal-clear views of the Italian Alps all around them. "What a playground," says Graham.

Once he reaches the bottom of the glacier, after following his group down the steep slope, Graham looks back at what the group have just skied.

"When you get down and you look back at what you've skied and you look at the crevasse field you've come around, it's just one of the best feelings in the world. We've laid our tracks on that mountain," says the Ski Sunday presenter, before venturing off through a powder field down through the valley.

Steep, deep and powdery, Graham certainly found it all on this, the latest addition to his search for the world's best ski runs.

results.title: World Superbike championship heads to Thailand: what to expect from the Chang International Circuit this weekend
results.body:
For round two of the 2018 World Superbike championship the series heads to Thailand and the Chang International Circuit. And for the first time in 77 races the series has a new leader.

Italian Marco Melandri on the Aruba.it Racing Ducati proudly sits atop the championship after taking both race wins at Phillip Island. Reigning world champion Jonathan Rea had, prior to the season opener, led the championship for 76 consecutive races on his way to three consecutive world championships.

If Melandri can claim victory in race one it will be only the second time in his WSBK career that he will have taken three consecutive race wins. The first and only time was in 2012 where the Italian took victory in race two at Aragon and followed that up by a double win in Brno. Last year Melandri took fourth and third in Chang and, following his performance in Australia last month, will be looking to improve on that this time around.

This is the fourth year the championship has visited Chang and to date the Kawasaki Racing Team have a 100% win record at the Thai circuit. Rea has the upper hand with four wins to team mate Sykes' two. Kawasaki has also claimed 11 of the 18 podiums over the three years of competition in Thailand.

Based on results in Australia where in recent years Rea and Kawasaki had been similarly dominant 2018 could be the year that Kawasaki's vice-like grip at Chang could be broken. Chang is the only track in the calendar where Ducati are yet to win in WSBK, but both Melandri and team mate Chaz Davies have secured podiums at the circuit.

One thing that hasn't changed from recent seasons after round one is the dominance of British riders. The five British riders competing the 2018 season are all in the top seven, with Melandri 1st, and Javier Fores 4th the only non Brits in the top seven. Dutchman Michael van der Mark riding for Yamaha completes the top eight, which is currently the preserve of four manufacturers, with each of Ducati, Kawasaki, Yamaha and Honda occupying two places each. One of those Hondas is ridden by former British Superbike champion Leon Camier who for 2018 has moved from the often unreliable MV Agusta. If the Honda is competitive as a package Camier should be challenging at the front and hopefully challenging the previous dominance of Kawasaki and Ducati.

The Supersport class got underway with echoes of the 2017 season. Last year Lucas Mahias took full advantage of the absence of the then reigning champion Kenan Sofuoglu taking the race win and a 25 point advantage over the hot favourite for the championship. Though Sofuoglu came back strongly, at one point claiming five wins from six races, Mahias held on to take the championship.

This year, while Sofuoglu raced in Phillip Island, he could only manage 13th place, leaving him 22 points behind Mahaias heading to Thailand. It has since been announced that Sofuoglu will miss round two. The Turkish rider originally injured himself at Magny Cours last season and a 150mph crash in free practice three in Australia has highlighted a bone fragility that needs more time to recover. The five-time Supersport champion has decided to sit out round two to allow the bone in question more time to heal, as well as to reduce the risk of further damage.

Mahias meantime will be keen to continue where he left off in Australia, knowing how strong a competitor a fully fit Sofuoglu can be. Last year he failed to take further advantage of Sofuoglu's absence, crashing out of the race in Thailand. This year Mahias has the confidence that being champion brings and will be well aware that any points will be better than no points. Whatever the outcome come Sunday should a fully fit Sofuoglu return for round three in Spain it could very much still be a case of game on such is his prowess on the 600cc machines.

After round one it is very much Yamaha who are in the ascendancy taking the first four places in the championship. In fifth place is British rider Luke Stapleford on the triple cylinder Triumph, with another triple cylinder machine in sixth, this time of Italian origins with Raffael de Rosa on the MV Agusta.

No one has been dominant so far in Thailand with three riders and three different manufacturers taking the wins to date. Reigning champion Mahias is yet to win at the circuit, as is Sofuoglu. The latter will have to wait at least one more year if he is to change that particular statistic.

results.title: Sajid Javid quashes plan for new coal mine in Northumberland
results.body:
The Communities Secretary Sajid Javid has denied permission to build a new coal mine in Northumberland, overruling the wishes of the local council and the recommendation of his own planning inspector.

The secretary of state said the proposed open-cast Highthorn mine near Druridge Bay would have a "very substantial" impact on greenhouse gas emissions and climate change, and on the character of the landscape. Mr Javid also found that "the proposal would not represent sustainable development".

Developer Banks Mining had said the mine would be a source of three million tonnes of coal over 10 years that would otherwise be imported, creating 100 jobs and generating £87m for the local area.

But campaigners argued that the mine would cause "massive environmental destruction right next to one of Northumberland's most beautiful and loved beaches".

The mine, which would have been the largest opencast site in the UK, was approved by Northumberland County Council and backed by planning inspector John Woolcock, before being called in for review by the secretary of state last year.

While acknowledging the environmental impact of the mine, the inspector had noted "a 'window' currently exists to use Highthorn coal" before coal plants are phased out in 2025 under the Government's existing energy policy.

Gavin Styles, managing director at Banks, slammed the Government's "absolutely perverse decision".

"The UK is still dependant on coal for a number of purposes, and at a time of great economic uncertainty, we firmly believe that the importance of securing investment in North East England, creating dozens of high quality local jobs, and opening up opportunities for regional suppliers to win substantial contracts could not be any clearer," he added.

Mr Styles suggested Banks would appeal the ruling, saying it "owed" its staff and customers "to not just leave things here".

Lynne Gargett, spokeswoman for the Save Druridge campaign, said: "The Save Druridge team is pleased that the secretary of state has understood the immense impact coal has had on climate change and also on communities which have had to live with opencast mines on their doorsteps."

results.title: What Kia Fleet is right for you?
results.body:
Whether it's European touring or a city nipper, Kia has the perfect model for the road your company's on

It's not often that a range of cars can accurately boast the cliche of "something for everyone", but the new Kia range is extensive enough to make an impression on every fleet manager.

Kia Motors has a reputation for exceptional and innovative car design and this is reflected in the company's recent triple win at the prestigious 2018 iF Design Awards, one of the world's most celebrated design competitions. The recent wins bring Kia's total to 15.

Kia is able to support most business mobility needs with its ever-expanding range of vehicles, from urban runarounds and crossovers to executive cars and electrified powertrains, moving the brand from challenger to established fixture for the people buying Britain's next generation of company cars.

Epic journeys

The latest entry to the competitive saloon space is the Kia Stinger Gran Turismo, styled by Gregory Guillaume at Kia's European design centre in Frankfurt and taking its inspiration from 1970s grand tourers. The Stinger melds classic gran turismo design with a spacious interior. Ideal for carrying four adults on a weighty continental road trip, the Stinger boasts high safety levels underpinned by an advanced high-strength steel body.

With an extensive range of advanced driver assistance systems available, the Stinger also comes with electronic stability control as standard. Its other standard safety features include autonomous emergency braking, a speed limit information function and hill-start assist control.

The Stinger's innovative driver attention warning system is designed to combat distracted driving by monitoring inputs from both vehicle and the driver and sounding a warning chime if it detects a dip in driver concentration; ideal for arduous journeys. The European New Car Assessment Programme (Euro NCAP) has also praised the Stinger for its passenger compartments remaining stable in the event of a collision, with high levels of protection for passengers of different statures in every seat.

The Stinger is available in rear-wheel drive and a range of petrol and diesel engines, and the high-performance 3.3-litre twin-turbocharged V6 petrol engine makes it the most powerful and fastest-accelerating Kia ever.

Compact driving

The Stonic compact crossover (also designed in Frankfurt) is Kia's most customisable car to date, with a huge choice of two-tone paint combinations and interior colours. Its sleek body is inspired by the company's larger SUVs and the car has already proved so popular it looks set to become one of Kia's best-sellers.

Among the Stonic's wide range of high-tech features is vehicle stability management, electronic stability control and six standard-fit airbags. Efficiency is key in the Stonic and it is powered by a range of Kia's most advanced petrol and diesel engines, all paired as standard with manual transmission.

The Stonic comes with Apple CarPlay™ and Android Auto™ as standard, and if you opt for the First Edition Stonic, you'll get an in-built satnav too.

City driving

A good city vehicle should be able to offer cheap motoring and reliability. Kia launched the Picanto in 2004 and has sold more than a million of them worldwide. Since then it's gone through a range of enhancements, making it a high performer on the agility, accuracy and reliability necessary for urban driving. But city driving doesn't always equal solo living and the third-generation Picanto (Kia's smallest European car but still one of the most spacious in its class) can easily accommodate family life with five doors and five seats.

As with all Kia models, these all come with the brand's unique seven-year/100,000 mile warranty.

results.title: Alice Roberts - Oxford's youngest crew member mastering the balance between Boat Race training and student life
results.body:
For a glimpse into the sacrifices made by the students competing in this weekend's Boat Race, look no further than the unusual life of Oxford's Alice Roberts, the 19-year-old undergraduate who wakes up for training as her housemates are stumbling home from nights out.

Roberts is no foreign import to these shores, no hired gun drafted by the university to do little more than eat, sleep and win the Boat Race.

She is a bona fide student, the youngest in her crew, who spends much of her year trying to juggle six hours of daily training with working towards a degree in philosophy and linguistics. She is even from Oxford itself, having grown up there and attended a state school in the city.

Rather than joining her fellow undergrads on the traditional cycle of hangovers and deadlines, Roberts studies and rows, rows and studies. It is a balancing act, and it can be a battle.

"Sometimes you get the balance wrong," she says. "But I'm learning. My housemates don't row, and sometimes I come downstairs and they have just got back in while I go off to train.

"I don't mind it so much, but there are definitely times when you do miss it, like when you are hanging out at home, sitting on the sofa, and then you look at your watch to see it's half past nine and you really should go to bed.

"You miss out on relationships, and it's not just when you are rowing. When you are not rowing, you need to be doing the work to catch up."

That commitment, and those sacrifices, are what makes defeat in the Boat Race so much harder to stomach. In her first race last year, Oxford's hopes of winning had sunk within the first few seconds as a dreadful start allowed Cambridge to immediately surge clear before eventually finishing in a record time of 18 minutes and 33 seconds.

It was "devastating", Roberts says. But it was easier for her, knowing she had possibly three more chances to make amends. "I was very aware it was different for me than for other members of the team," she says. "It's easy for me to look at the bigger picture."

That bigger picture shows that Roberts is the only returning member of last year's crew. It also shows that Cambridge leads the overall standings by 42 victories to Oxford's 30.

"If I looked back having lost four races, it would be frustrating," she says. "But there is a reason you keep doing it. I don't believe there is anybody who does sport just to win. How can you do it every day if you don't like doing it?"

There lies the crux. Yes, it's a harder life than she could be living. More stress, more pressure, less time. But it's a way of life on which a certain breed of person can thrive. "It's a different kind of intensity, which I like. I am used to it, and I am kind of nervous for it to stop."

results.title: New York restaurants
results.body:
Expert guide to New York Overview Hotels Attractions Restaurants Free Nightlife

The best restaurants in New York, from Michelin-starred dining to budget options. By Douglas Rogers, Telegraph Travel's destination expert.

Eight million people from every country on Earth live in New York, so the range of culinary experiences is bewildering. The fine-dining scene changes amazingly fast, with new trends and movements springing up all the time.

Best hotels in New York

New York chefs are always innovating. The artisanal and locavore (local food) movement is all the rage the world over, but what to do in a city of eight-lane traffic and skyscrapers? Easy: grow it on the roof. Richard Farnabe, the executive chef at the Soho Grand, has planted an organic garden on the 17-storey hotel, growing herbs, vegetables, micro greens - and more than 27 varieties of heirloom tomatoes.

Whatever the trends, there are always the classics, and New York does them like no other. Don't miss the oysters at Grand Central Oyster Bar in the basement of the famous train terminal, going strong since 1913; or a Porterhouse steak at the venerable Brooklyn institution Peter Luger (established 1887) - for my money the world's finest steakhouse. Bring cash, though. Steak for two costs $85 (£53) - and they don't take credit cards

£££ Eleven Madison Park

Eleven Madison Park was crowned the World's Best Restaurant in April 2017. Enough said. Swiss culinary genius Daniel Humm's soaring space above Madison Square Park is grand enough: skyscraper ceilings, towering tree arrangements, sky-box dining suites. But the endlessly reinvented food is what you come for. The diagram menu that made the space famous has been replaced with a tasting menu dedicated to all local New York farm and sea ingredients: oysters, scallops, lobster, duck, and aged beef. The foie gras terrine with plum and bitter almond is a delight, and the sturgeon presented as take on a New York City bagel is mesmerising. Call months in advance to get a table.

Address: 11 Madison Ave, 10010

Getting there: N, R, 6 to 23rd St

Contact: 001 212 889 0905; elevenmadisonpark.com

Opening times: Fri-Sun, noon-1pm, 5.30pm-10pm; Mon-Thu, 5.30pm-10pm

Price: tasting menu, $295 lunch and dinner (including gratuity)

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: essential

The Restaurant at the Mark

French chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten's fine dining temple located in the fabulously restored Mark Hotel is the ultimate blue chip Manhattan experience: exquisite cuisine combined with high-grade people-watching. At lunch, Upper East Side heiresses with dogs in their purses pick at salads, oysters and foie gras while their town cars idle outside; at dinner, Wall Street tycoons, Madison Avenue millionaires, and upscale auction house aficionados come for perfectly balanced Vongerichten specialities such as a tuna tartare and grilled black sea bass with fennel. The scene in the adjacent pink-lit bar area could have been choreographed by Vogue; take one of the cowhide chairs, sample a signature kumquat mojito, and check out the supermodels.

Address: 25 E 77th St., 10075

Getting there: 6 to 77th St

Contact: 001 212 606 3030; themarkrestaurantnyc.com

Opening times: daily, 7am-1am

Price: lunch around $55, dinner around $75

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: essential

The 21 Club

Opened in 1922 as a Greenwich Village gin mill before moving to its current Midtown location in 1929, at the height of Prohibition, "21", as it is affectionately known, is the last of the original speakeasies. Don't let the "Club" in its name put you off. It's open to all - although there's always a uniformed doorman on duty, you can't get in with jeans or trainers, and they only recently allowed men to dine without ties. New chef Sylvain Delpique has helped attract a foodie crowd with standout dishes such as his surprisingly tasty Chicken Paillard, and a fancy cocktail menu. Try the classic Southside, made with Tanqueray gin and muddled mint.

Address: 21 W 52nd St, 10019

Getting there: B, D, F, M to 47th-50th Sts-Rockefeller Center; E, M to Fifth Ave-53rd St

Contact: 001 212 582 7200; 21club.com

Opening times: Mon-Fri, noon-2.30pm, 5.30pm-10.30pm; Sat, noon-2.30pm, 5.30pm-11pm

Price: lunch around $65, dinner around $80

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: essential

Peter Luger

Arguably the greatest steakhouse in America, this amber-lit, wood-panelled gem in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has been going strong since 1887. Frequently name-checked in The Sopranos, it has been owned by the Forman family of Brooklyn since 1950, and is famous for its rare, juicy porterhouse steaks (the owners always get the first choice of cuts from New York's meat markets). Take a seat in the brass-chandeliered front room, next to politicians, mobsters, celebrities and sports stars, and let one of the famously surly Teutonic waiters tell you what you're having. Sides to go for are creamed spinach and a plate of tomatoes. Warning: it's pricey, and bring cash: they do not accept credit cards.

Address: 178 Broadway, Brooklyn, 11211

Getting there: J, M, Z to Marcy Ave

Contact: 001 718 387 7400; peterluger.com

Opening times: Mon-Thu, 11.45am-9.45pm; Fri, Sat, 11.45am-10.45pm; Sun, 12.45pm-9.45pm

Price: lunch around $60, dinner around $80

Payment type: credit cards not accepted

Reservations: essential

Sardi's

Every tourist loves a Broadway show, and this venerable eatery just off the Great White Way is an essential pre- or post-theatre dinner stop. It's been going strong since 1927, and its red banquettes, ornate lampshades and hundreds of caricatures of showbiz celebrities - Liza Minnelli, Joan Rivers, Jackie Gleason - adorning the walls are as much part of the scene as the jumbo crab cakes. The Tony Awards - theatre's Oscars - were dreamed up in a booth there, and every night there's a special discounted menu for Screen Actors Guild (Equity) cardholders. Jumbo crab cakes aside, the Shrimp Sardi - sautéed shrimp in garlic sauce - is legendary.

Address: 234 W 44th St, 10036

Getting there: 1, 2, 3, 7, N, Q, R, S to Times Square-42nd St

Contact: 001 212 221 8440; sardis.com

Opening times: Tue-Sat, 11.30am-11.30pm; Sun, noon-7pm

Price: lunch around $40, dinner around $60

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: essential

Old Homestead Steakhouse

The nondescript brick façade and kitschy sculpture of a cow outside claiming "We're the King of Beef" may not promise much, but this historic beef temple is carnivore heaven. This is the oldest steakhouse in the city: it was established by Harry Sherry in 1868 and is still run by the same family. Its clubby, carpeted interior consists of three narrow, wood-panelled, gold-leaf-ceilinged dining rooms set over two floors, and overseen by burly waiters with meat-slab forearms. Of the dozen cuts on offer, sliced at your table, opt for the Gotham rib steak, prime porterhouse or center cut sirloin, seasoned with their own herbs and spices. King of beef indeed. The epic wine menu is as heavy as a T-bone.

Address: 56 Ninth Ave, 10011

Getting there: A, C, E to 14th St; L to Sixth Ave

Contact: 001 212 242 9040; theoldhomesteadsteakhouse.com

Opening times: Mon-Thu, noon-10.30pm; Fri, noon-11.30pm; Sat, 1pm-11.30pm; Sun 1pm-9.30pm

Price: lunch around $65, dinner around $75

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: essential

Balthazar

In the heart of SoHo, this timeless French/American bistro from British-born restaurateur Keith McNally is a modern classic. Enter through the curtained doorway and you find yourself in a hallowed, gold-lit space of high ceilings, mirrored walls and tiled floors. Diners tuck into oysters and steak frites at cosy wood tables or red-leather booths in the main dining area, while designer-clad women and suited men wait their turn sipping cocktails and champagne at the elegant marble counter to the right. This neighbourhood bar and burger joint is popular with the preppy set and pretty Upper East Side gals in fur coats - very Gossip Girl. Opened in 1972, its tin-pressed ceiling, wood counter and veteran staff are part of the rustic charm - and its bacon cheeseburger is one of the juiciest in town. In summer, there are a few outside tables to sit at but the place to be is in the bar, sipping a pale ale or Bloody Mary chatting to the aproned servers about the baseball scores or moaning about the mayor. Classic.

Address: 1291 Third Ave, 10021

Getting there: 6 to 77th St

Contact: 001 212 744 0585

Opening times: Sun, 11.30am-1am; Mon-Thu, 11.30am-2am; Fri, Sat, 11.30am-3am

Price: cheeseburger $12.25

Payment type: credit cards not accepted

Reservations: not possible

Dos Toros Taqueria

If it's a quick bite you're after, I defy anyone who has tasted the guacamole-filled pollo asado (grilled chicken) quesadilla to not come back here for more. This is Mexican food via San Francisco made from super-fresh ingredients, with friendly service and in funky surroundings, with informal bar-stool-style seating at tables made from reclaimed wood. The menu is a simple list of burritos, tacos and quesadillas, and you go to the counter and tell the staff what you want and which extras to add. One burrito will keep you going all day. There are now multiple locations across the city, including Battery Park City, Upper East Side and Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

Address: 137 Fourth Ave, 10003

Getting there: 4, 5, 6, L, N, Q, R to 14th St-Union Square

Contact: 001 212 677 7300; dostoros.com

Opening times: Sun, Mon, 11.30am-10.30pm; Tue-Sat, 11.30am-11pm

Price: quesadillas and burritos around $8

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: not necessary

Katz's Delicatessen

In the early 1900s, the Lower East Side was home to a thriving Eastern European Jewish community, and dozens of kosher delis lined the streets selling knishes, blintzes, borscht and strudel. Today only a few remain, of which Katz's, opened in 1888, is the best, famous for the "I'll have what she's having" orgasm scene in When Harry Met Sally. Ask for the booth where Meg Ryan and Billy Crystal sat in the famous scene. You're given a ticket at the entrance and line up at glass counters to order basic deli fare: pickles, knockwurst, salami, frankfurters, potato salad and all manner of juicy pastrami, Reubens and beef brisket sandwiches. Four US Presidents have dined here, Bill Clinton once devouring two hot dogs and a pastrami-on-rye sandwich in one sitting.

Address: 205 East Houston St, 10002

Getting there: F to Second Ave

Contact: 001 212 254 2246; katzsdelicatessen.com

Opening times:

Price: Katz's Pastrami Hot Sandwich, $21.45

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: not possible

Shake Shack

What started as a hot dog cart in Madison Square Park in 2001 is now a national franchise; the hot dogs having been joined by a spectacular selection of gourmet burgers and shakes. As for the cart, it's now a busy kiosk on the south side of the park with a queue lined up around the block and garden tables outside that are permanently packed. The ShackBurger is the stuff of burger legends and what people wait in line for, but we like the SmokeShack: a cheeseburger topped with smoked bacon, cherry pepper and a tangy house sauce.

Address: Madison Square Park

Getting there: N, R, 6 to 23rd St

Contact: 001 212 889 6600; shakeshack.com

Opening times: daily, 11am-10.30pm

Price: hot dogs from $4.29, burgers from $5.55

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: not possible

Pok Pok NY

Portland, Oregon, chef Andy Ricker began serving authentic Thai and Vietnamese street food - stewed duck leg in soy broth, pork belly curry in ginger and the like - in his home state, and it became so popular he opened in New York. This Red Hook, Brooklyn, outlet is the one to go to. Crammed with local hipsters and Thai devotees from Manhattan, the tiny interior and the back garden with umbrellas hung with fairy lights recalls a beach front food stall in Phuket - and you are close to the water here, too. Dishes are served street-style in plastic bowls or metal plates, but knowing his audience you can also get finely crafted cocktails. What to order? Hoi Thawt - cripsy crêpe filled with mussels, egg, garlic and chives. Try the second outlet at 137 Rivington Street in the Lower East Side if Brooklyn is too much of a haul. They do not take reservations.

Address: 117 Columbia St, 11231

Getting there: F, G to Bergen St

Contact: 001 718 923 9322; pokpokny.com

Opening times: Mon-Fri, 5.30pm-10pm; Sat, Sun, noon-10pm

Price: lunch and dinner around $35

Payment type: credit cards accepted

Reservations: not possible

Hometown Bar-B-Que

This is exactly how I like my barbecue; Texas-style, served by the weight and slapped unceremoniously on a silver tray to be eaten with my hands. Hometown is made up of two adjoining barns decorated with American flags and vintage beer signs, with a small stage where bluegrass bands play in the evening. Grab a craft beer from the bar so you can drink while you queue for the meat counter, and then seat yourself. The brisket is perfectly succulent with a caramelized "bark"; the beef ribs are mighty, falling away from the bone; and the Korean sticky ribs are the surprise hit. In short, eat everything. Twice. Located in the quirky enclave of Red Hook, with its cobbled streets and artist studios, there's no subway here, but it's worth the journey. Afterwards head to Sunny's saloon (253 Conover St), a cornerstone of the community that's been around since 1890.

results.title: LA Galaxy announce Zlatan Ibrahimovic signing with full-page newspaper advert
results.body:
Zlatan Ibrahimovic says he is ready to win silverware with Los Angeles Galaxy after a full-page advert in Friday's LA Times confirmed his move to the MLS club from Manchester United.

The advert, in which Ibrahimovic was pictured in the white Galaxy kit, carried a message from the 36-year-old saying "Dear Los Angeles, you're welcome".

He becomes the latest high-profile player to move to the MLS in the latter part of his career -- following the likes of David Beckham, Steven Gerrard, Thierry Henry and Frank Lampard.

Former England captain Beckham won the MLS Cup twice after joining Galaxy in 2007 and became an iconic figure for the growth of the game in a country hooked on more traditional American sports like NFL and baseball.

Ibrahimovic, while in the latter stages of a glittering career, could have a similar impact.

The Swede left United on Thursday when the Premier League club agreed to terminate his contract and said the move is about writing another chapter in a storied career in which he won league titles in Italy, the Netherlands, Spain and France.

"After being in Europe, winning 33 trophies, playing in the best teams in the world, playing with the best players in the world, I wanted to come to the U.S. and play my game there," Ibrahimovic said in an interview in the LA Times.

"I wanted people to enjoy my game there and to win. And I chose the Galaxy to do that.

Dan Beckerman, the president of entertainment giant AEG, the Galaxy's parent organisation, said Ibrahimovic would become one of the biggest stars in the Hollywood city.

"He's giving up a lot to come here," Beckerman told the LA Times. He's made it clear he's coming here to win championships. It's not about the money.

"L.A. is a place for stars, and he's going to be one of the brightest stars that's ever played in this market. In any sport."

Ibrahimovic, who scored 62 goals in 116 games for Sweden and played for some of Europe's biggest clubs including Inter Milan, AC Milan, Barcelona and Paris St Germain, is reported to have accepted $3 million over two season to play for Galaxy, a huge wage cut from his United salary.

Ibrahimovic justified United's outlay when he scored 28 times in all competitions in his first season at Old Trafford.

But after a knee injury sustained nearly a year ago he has managed only seven appearances this season.

Despite that Ibrahimovic, who boasts nearly five million Twitter followers and owns a clothing brand, said he was ready for action.

"I am ready to go now," Ibrahimovic said. "First of all, I'm there to play football. I'm not there for something else. My first objective is to play football and do what I'm good at.

"I'm excited to come over and to get the experience with the Galaxy and to explore how the football is there. I want to be part of it and make it better."

Ibrahimovic's first action for Galaxy could even come against city rivals Los Angeles Football Club on March 31.

results.title: Michael McIntyre, Big World Tour, review: 'like an emergency air-drop of medicinal laughing-gas'
results.body:
Michael McIntyre's latest show is like an emergency air-drop of medicinal laughing-gas.

You thought the winter was over, then it came back, and apparently it will keep coming back until we're all glum as hell. "How many f--king beasts are we going to have?" wails British comedy's jester-in-chief, during his early bounding-about bit at Nottingham Arena, squeezed into a smart suit and resembling at points a pirouetting hippo.

"Are we going to be opening the fridge in the summer, 'Look, it's a mini-mini-mini beast!'" Not the greatest gag he has ever told, perhaps, but as ever McIntyre has a knack for reading the collective mood and relaying his observations as if they were essentially crowd-sourced.

As the title suggests, this is his furthest-reaching show to date. He went across Europe last summer (he's big in Bergen); his vaguely Asiatic features (a source of confusion even among his family) were greeted with admiration in Hong Kong ("I knew they fancied me because they were lowering their pollution masks to flirt"); South Africa has just received him; they whooped him up in New York; and after his extensive UK tour, he'll get to go back to Australia.

results.title: Maria Bamford, Leicester Square Theatre, review: 'a triumphant London debut'
results.body:
How do you solve a problem like Maria Bamford? Tickets sold out months in advance for the US comedian's first ever London shows - a good omen that might fill another performer with confidence, but you wouldn't know it from her jittery, apologetic persona.

Taking the stage in a black leather jacket embroidered with flowers, the 47-year-old reminds the audience her "distracting slight tremor" is medical, rather than down to nerves, before immediately adding that it suits her act to a tee ("Weakness is the brand!").

Bamford has no shortage of influential fans - comedy super-producer Judd Apatow has called her "the funniest woman on earth" - but she seems actively to shy away from success. Her first sitcom, The Maria Bamford Show, was recorded alone in her bedroom. Her 2012 live show was filmed in front of an audience of two - her parents.

results.title: How Dropbox founder Drew Houston turned down Apple to make his own billions
results.body:

Dropbox, founded by Houston in 2007, is today set to launch a $9 billion float in New York, the culmination of an 11 year journey for the cloud storage company that provides a simple way to save and share files online.

Its rapid growth saw the Dropbox become a viral hit with consumers, and its popularity was such that the late Apple chief executive Steve Jobs once tried to buy it - then threatened to destroy it.

results.title: Why you're likely to learn a new song if you take a tuk-tuk in Sri Lanka
results.body:
Megan Brownrigg wins £250 for her account of a how a bumpy bus ride led to a snapshot of rush-hour hospitality.

Asking everyone to sing on a speeding bus in a foreign land was always going to be ambitious. But this was Sri Lanka, where smiles and spontaneity seemed standard currency. A song should be a piece of cake.

We weren't meant to be on a bus. We were meant to be driving a tuk-tuk - 932 miles (1,500km) in 10 days. Considering that we'd not yet made it to a checkpoint before nightfall, getting on a bus heading in the wrong direction was an indulgent detour. But as part of our expedition we'd been challenged to learn a local song. Our taskmaster would spot shortcutting a mile off, so it was time to get creative and pool resources: five idiots in two tuk-tuks.

"How about catching a bus and asking them to teach us a song?" Dave suggested. On an isolated road, with no idea if there were any buses, we agreed; it was a great idea. Twenty minutes later, three of us were surf-balancing in the corridor of a hurtling bus; the other two were in the tuk-tuks in hot pursuit.

We quickly clocked we weren't the crowd-pleasers we'd envisaged. If our fellow passengers did understand our broken Sinhalese, they were doing a stellar job of pretending they didn't. One woman spoke English, but her wary eyes persuaded a silent pact between us; I couldn't expose her bilingual talents. Commuting, as it turns out, is a universally miserable activity.

As we alighted the bus in the next town, Sri Lanka's magic returned in the shape of an afternoon monsoon. Glints of light danced across umbrellas and saris, in a tango of jewel colours. Through raindrops, we watched an afternoon rush forced into slow-motion.

But when we returned to our trusty tuk-tuks, my heart sank. My unzipped rucksack revealed the nook where my camera should be. The white noise of panic soon overwhelmed the beauty of the shower.

Ryan insisted we retrace our steps. We scoured the spot of our flying departure. Nothing. We trundled back to town in silence as I tried not to be just a sulky traveller who'd lost a gadget.

Ryan's voice splintered my sulk; "You're joking? We'll be five minutes." He wasn't talking to me. He was on the phone. In the sweaty, euphoric confusion that followed, I met the Sri Lankan man who took the trouble to return something to a stranger in rush-hour. He would take nothing but a selfie as a thank you.

By jumping on a bus and flinging a camera out of a tuk-tuk, we gained a true snapshot of Sri Lanka; the people who live there.

A while later, we pulled up by a roadside shack. In the jungle dusk, the girls generously paused to teach us a local song. We sang it aloud in our tuk-tuk, long into the night after we'd lost our map.

Some things are better not found.

results.title: Parsons Green terrorist is jailed for at least 34-years after the judge rules he lied about only being 18
results.body:
An Iraqi asylum seeker who planted the Parsons Green Tube bomb has been jailed for life and ordered to serve a minimum of 34-years.

Ahmed Hassan, who entered Britain illegally in 2015, was found guilty of attempted murder, after leaving a the explosive device packed with shrapnel on a rush hour District Line train on September 15 last year.

More than 50 people were injured when the bomb partially detonated sending a fireball down the busy carriage.

But scores could have been killed if the device, which was packed with 400g of 'Mother of Satan' explosives, had functioned as he intended.

Sentencing him, Mr Justice Haddon-Cave said: "Your intention that morning was to kill as many members of the British public as possible by planting the IED on a busy commuter Tube train."

The judge said he had no doubt Hassan was a "very dangerous and devious" individual.

The judge said he was satsified Hassan - who claimed he was only 18 - had trained with Isil, but also said he believed he had lied about his age.

He said he sentenced him on the basis that he was over 21, which meant he received a much longer prison term.

During his trial, the Old Bailey heard how Hassan had wanted to avenge the death of his father, who he claimed had been killed in Iraq.

During his asylum application, the teenager told Home Office officials, that he had been trained to kill by Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Isil), but denied being sent to the UK as a sleeper terrorist.

Hassan had been referred to the government's anti-radicalisation Prevent programme, but kept his murderous plan secret from officials, who believed he was engaging with them.

Hassan used a £20 Amazon voucher he won for being voted student of the year at his local college, to buy one of the key chemicals online, and built the bomb in the conservatory of his foster parents' home in Sunbury-on-Thames, while they were on holiday in Blackpool.

On the morning of September 15 last year, Hassan left his home and caught a train to Wimbledon carrying his bomb inside a Lidl bag.

He set the timer in Wimbledon then got off the train one stop before the bomb partially exploded on the floor of the carriage at Parsons Green.

Twenty-three passengers suffered burns, with some describing their hair catching fire and their clothes melting in the blast.

And 28 more suffered cracked ribs and other crush injuries in the stampede to get out of the platform via a narrow stairway.

Hassan destroyed his phone before feeling London with more than £2,000 in cash, but was arrested by police at the Port of Dover the following day.

Hassan's foster parents, Penny and Ron Jones, who were awarded an MBE in 2010, accused the authorities of failing to warn them to look out for signs of radicalisation.

A review of Hassan's dealings with Prevent is under way.

results.title: Ant and Dec lose Suzuki advertising contract following drink driving charge
results.body:
Car manufacturer Suzuki have confirmed they will no longer be working with Ant and Dec in the wake of Ant McPartlin's arrest and subsequent drink driving charge.

The company confirmed the rumours that they would cut ties with the presenting duo on Friday in a statement. "Suzuki are withdrawing their advertising campaign with Ant and Dec. No further material featuring the duo will be aired and Suzuki's endorsement deal with the pair has come to an end," the statement said.

"We agree with ITV and Ant and Dec that it was the correct decision not to broadcast Saturday Night Takeaway this weekend. As a car brand we recognise the seriousness of Ant's charge. We completely support Ant's decision to seek treatment."

The company has said, however, that it will continue to sponsor the final two episodes of the current series of Saturday Night Takeaway, which run for the next two weeks and will see a series finale in Florida.

Ant and Dec have been advertising Suzuki since striking a lucrative deal with the car brand in December 2015. Part of their remit involves the Geordie duo surprising members of the public with Suzuki cars.

Suzuki appear to have removed all of the adverts featuring Ant and Dec from their YouTube page.

results.title: How to ski as a family of five
results.body:
Taking the family to the slopes is hard enough when you have one or two children. Even ski fanatics the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have only managed one long ski weekend as a family since becoming parents. But add a third child into the mix - as the Royal couple will this April - and a whole new set of organisational and monetary headaches comes in to play.

From holiday packages and hotel rooms to lift-pass deals and high-speed quad chairlifts, family ski holidays are set up for foursomes. As a mother of three myself, my own bugbear is that few hotels cater for families with more than two children.

Even self-driving is more challenging - when a family room sleeps only four and you're forced to pay for two rooms, that cheap overnight stop to break the journey to the Alps may seem an unjustifiable expense.

We've been known to stretch the truth by saying our youngest is still in a cot (he's seven), then smuggling him in with an airbed after check-in.

Quite apart from the cost, which admittedly may not be an issue for William and Kate, there's the ski resort logistics. Two of you, three littlies - the maths doesn't work on the hill. Who goes solo on a two-person chairlift? Who copes alone on the T-bar? Who has to toboggan by themselves?

After two ski holidays à cinq, we've done the research. Here's what you need to know if you're taking the tribe.

1. Book early

Family and connecting rooms in hotels and chalets are like gold dust during peak ski season; if you don't want to split the family in two, booking early is essential for five. Not only will you bag the biggest rooms, you'll usually get the best price. Flights are nearly always cheapest when booked early too. Sign up for alerts from airlines to get the heads up as soon as flights are released.

2. Consider self-catering

If that third child is threatening to price your family out of the ski holiday market, self-catering could bring the price back within reach. My quick search in March for three-star packages to snow-sure Tignes in France during Christmas week 2018 (including flights and transfers) found a self-catering option at around £400 cheaper per person than a catered chalet, and £500 cheaper than a hotel.

Plan meals ahead to save stress when you get there. If driving, fill every space with breakfast essentials, on-mountain snacks and frozen meals for the first few hectic days (do not refreeze!).

3. Or, let chalet hosts take the strain

If the thought of cooking and cleaning on top of everything else threatens to tip you over the edge, do it the Royal way and let someone else look after you - the cost may be well worth it for the added holiday freedom. Staying in a chalet or chalet-hotel makes for a lower-hassle holiday and, if you go with family specialists such as Esprit, Mark Warner or Ski Famille, there's access to child care.

Even simple services like collecting the youngest from lessons helps when you can't be in three places at once. Cooked breakfast, afternoon tea and a three-course dinner is included, often with unlimited wine. Inclusive packages also help you budget by taking the guesswork out of how much you'll spend in resort.

4. Train them well

Parental juggling on the ski hill is similar to the juggling families of five have to do at theme parks, where one adult/one child ratios are the norm. Manage expectations when skiing together, making sure children understand they need to be patient, stay together and allow for differing abilities. Pick wide cruisy pistes, ensuring the kids are in front of you so you can keep an eye on everyone. For après activities it's best to steer clear of those that need a one adult to one child ratio, like tobogganing, unless you can rope in an extra adult.

5. Take grandparents/friends/the nanny

When there are two of you and three of them, evening up the numbers by holidaying with another adult - or two - helps lighten the load, especially if (like the Royals) the kids are all under five, or the whole family are ski virgins.

6. Make sure you sit together on flights

Don't assume that because you're a family, you'll be seated together. If the plane is busy - and let's face it they usually are in school holidays - it's quite possible you'll be split up. And when your family isn't divisible by two, it's even more likely someone could end up alone. Minimise the risk by checking in early or pay extra to pre-book seats.

7. Make the most of the baggage allowance

You may have a lot of kit to take with three kids - but you don't have to pay for an extra bag. On most airlines, children from age two have the same free checked baggage and hand baggage allowance as adults, so forget cute mini backpacks for the littlies and make the most of it.

8. Get in the car

Once your youngest hits two, you'll be paying full whack on flights for five. If you're willing to take the pain of a long drive to the mountains, you'll not only save some cash but can stuff the car full of kid-paraphernalia and food as well as your ski kit.

9. Get the best hotel deal

Once your youngest is out of a cot, most hotels won't allow more than four in a room, no matter how willing you are to sleep the youngest top-to-toe or bring an airbed. Forking out for two rooms can double the cost of an overnight stay and, unless kids are older, most families don't want to be split up anyway.

Smuggling one of them in isn't great for sticking to fire regulations, and big family rooms are rare, so the best bet is to look for discounts on the second room. At Sofitel most suites only accommodate a family of four but some hotels in the chain knock 50 per cent off a second room over a weekend. Novotel offers 50 per cent off a second room for two children.

10. Factor in lift passes

Lift passes for five make up a large chunk of the cost of a winter holiday, so choosing a resort with good deals can save a lot. Children may ski free up to ages four or five - but in some resorts (such as Zermatt in Switzerland) it's up to age nine. Most places offer reduced rates for younger children, but some also give discounts for teenagers.

Family passes are most common in France and can work out well, with everyone in the group, including adults, paying a child rate. They're usually based on a family of four, so for a family of five, always plan to get a separate pass for the youngest, as it will be the cheapest.

The family pass offered in the Trois Vallées resorts in France (Courchevel, Méribel, Val Thorens) is a notable exception - it's available to families with up to seven children.

The International Ski Federation (FIS) keeps track of global prices for lift passes. Compare prices and discounts at snowkidz.com.

11. Get ahead with mountain navigation

Leading the gang around the mountain is stressful if you don't know where you're going. Lessons will help the children even they're competent skiers or snowboarders, and leave you free to spend a morning doing reconnaissance, getting to know which pistes you'll enjoy together and which lifts to avoid for example, without the worry of keeping tabs on everyone as you do it.

12. Ask for help on lifts

When you need an extra pair of hands, to watch out for your child on a chairlift for example, don't be afraid ask other adults - most people don't mind in our experience. On drag and chairlifts shout ahead to the lift operators when approaching the top as they will slow down the lift to avoid mishaps.

13. Holiday with another family

Going as a group (especially if your friends have fewer children) will bring costs down, keep the kids entertained and mean there are extra adults to help. Airport transfers may work out cheaper and easier when you travel in a large party, their children may be able to share bedrooms with yours, and you're likely to get a better per person price on accommodation.

14. Shave £££ off the food bill

Mountain restaurants can be expensive when there are two of you, let alone five. Thankfully, more resorts now have easy access picnic rooms where you can eat your own food (which could be shop- or chalet-bought sandwiches if you don't want to make them) without shivering on the slopes. Swanky Le Lodge in Val d'Isère, France, which opened for the 2016/17 ski season, up the mountain near the nursery slopes is a good example of how resorts are upping their game.

Alternatively, heading down to the resort village for lunch can shave a little off the lunch bill, as can venturing out of resort central to cheaper eateries in the evening. Order savvy and choose dishes to share tapas-style to avoid wasting food.

results.title: 25 England supporters detained overnight for drunkenly throwing beer bottles at Dutch police officers
results.body:
Dutch police say they detained 25 England supporters overnight after drunken fans threw beer bottles at officers ahead of a friendly match between the Netherlands and England.

Police say riot police were deployed to downtown Amsterdam to deal with the rowdy supporters. Police detained the England fans for offenses including public disorder.

England will play the Netherlands at the Amsterdam Arena on the southern edge of the Dutch capital. Police say they plan to beef up security before and after Friday's match.

About 1,500 England fans traveled to the Dutch capital for the match.

results.title: Theresa May sets up Downing Street committee to boost female entrepreneurship after Telegraph campaign
results.body:
Theresa May has set up a Downing Street committee to boost the number of women starting businesses just weeks after the Telegraph launched a campaign to help female entrepreneurs.

The task force, which will meet every two weeks, will ensure all policy developed by the Government considers the impact on women and focuses on increasing their role in politics, business and society as a whole.

It comes just weeks after the launch of a Telegraph campaign to champion women in business and tackle the unfairness of startup funding between the two genders.

The committee of peers, MPs and policy experts will focus on a set of key goals and will also look at how to end violence against women and girls...

results.title: Bank of England policymaker adds to speculation of rate rise in May
results.body:
A top policymaker at the Bank of England has added to speculation of an interest rate hike in May in a speech on Friday.

Gertjan Vlieghe, widely regarded as a dovish member of the central bank's rate setting committee, told an audience of businesses in Birmingham that he believed a tighter labour market would soon require a rate rise.

Mr Vlieghe said that unemployment was still an important measure of likely wage inflation. As such, provided signs carried on suggesting "that a tight labour market is actually pushing up domestic inflationary pressures", interest rates would need to be raised.

The economist made similar signals on rates in a speech given last September ahead of the Bank raising interest rates last November. He compared his reading of present data with that seen before the Autumn rate rise.

"Since then, the data have shifted further in the direction that warrants a continuation of the removal of monetary stimulus over the forecast period," he said. He added that two or three quarter-of-a-percentage point rises over this period were justified based on the current outlook for the economy.

However, Mr Vlieghe reaffirmed his cautious approach to rate hikes warning that, as rates were already so low, there was "less room to respond to downside risk than to upside risk, which means that patience is warranted when tightening policy".

The policymaker also analysed recent movements in unemployment levels and wages in his speech. The link between wage growth and unemployment levels referred to by economists as the Philips Curve was still strong, he argued.

Reasons to doubt this link in recent years were most likely due high levels of under-employment - when workers are employed but keen to have additional hours - and the public sector pay cap. Employees have been less able to switch to public sector roles, which are restricted to 1pc growth per year, in order to boost their salaries. As a result the case for a private sector pay raise had been harder to make.

The future outlook for wages was more positive, with many sectors of the economy showing that workers were managing to win raises. If inflation was kept at close to 2pc, and unemployment remained low, workers could expect wage growth of between 3-3.5pc, according to Mr Vlieghe. If productivity were to improve, earnings would also pick up at a greater pace.

Recent minutes from the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee meeting showed that two policymakers voted to raise rates from 0.5pc to 0.75pc immediately.

results.title: Troy Townsend: Black players avoid social media because of racial abuse - they must be given a platform to speak about it
results.body:
The anti-racism educator Troy Townsend, who stunned Gareth Southgate with a presentation on the racist abuse leading black footballers experience on social media, says that the comments the England manager referred to this week are "par for the course".

Townsend, education manager at equality organisation Kick It Out, said it is an open secret many leading black players avoid social media interaction because of the racial abuse, and the comments that he showed Southgate during a presentation at St George's Park were just a small sample of a major problem. Townsend called on the social media companies to do more to regulate users and also said that he hoped black players could come together to speak out about the effect the abuse has on them.

Speaking in Amsterdam on Thursday at his press conference ahead of the friendly against Holland, Southgate said that English football should get its own house in order before criticising other nations for racism, including World Cup finals hosts Russia. Southgate described the racist responses to Steven Gerrard's Instagram post in December 2015 congratulating the England Under-16s on beating Brazil as "disgusting".

Townsend, father of Crystal Palace winger Andros, made his presentation to leading figures at the FA including Southgate, women's senior team manager Phil Neville; technical director Dan Ashworth; Under-17s World Cup-winning coach Steve Cooper and women's coach Mo Marley. Townsend said: "I included some of the comments in the presentation to show the impact of winning the game but also what the players have to deal with when they are active on social media.

"In the picture were seven black players and four white players. The comments included, 'Is this the England squad or the Senegal squad?'; 'It looks like Nigeria's team'; 'Everyone else sees four white players, I see seven black players'; 'Seven out of 11 are non-English, what's happening to this country?'; 'Where are the English lads?'

"These kinds of comments are absolutely par for the course. Everyone keeps asking why are our players not interacting on social media. Because they are being driven away from it. You get the players saying, 'Oh, we don't read the criticism'. But there's a bit of our nature that will always read the comments. One week you've scored a goal and everyone loves you. Next week you have a bad game and say sorry to the fans, and that's often when the negative comments come on the back of it."

Southgate has said he wants his coaches to be aware of the abuse that players are suffering on social media and be able to support and empathise with them. Townsend visits clubs all across the football hierarchy and runs workshops introducing academy boys and professionals to diversity and equality across race, gender and sexuality. He has worked closely with Liverpool before and after their recent trip to Spartak Moscow where Rhian Brewster was racially abused in Uefa Youth League tie.

Townsend says that the problem needs the help of social media companies to regulate. He also thinks it would have an effect if black players were given a platform to speak about the abuse they suffer. "We need to use the power of the players' voice," he said. "I don't think we use it enough. I know Yaya Toure has spoken up a bit and I have a video of him talking about the impact that abuse had on him. I would love to see a powerful video made by players about the hatred being spouted towards them. Ultimately the power is with the social media companies."

results.title: Credit Suisse to hike bosses' pay despite another loss
results.body:
Credit Suisse is risking another shareholder backlash after unveiling plans to hike total pay for top bosses including chief executive Tidjane Thiam, despite posting a loss for 2017.

The Switzerland-based bank, which employs around 5,500 people in London, today proposed boosting pay and potential bonuses for 12 executives by 5.5pc more than a scheme it ditched last year in the face of investor opposition.

Overall pay for the dozen bosses fell 4pc last year to SFR69.9m (£52.3m), while Mr Thiam took home 5pc less at SFR9.7m francs.

Credit Suisse made a SFR983m loss last year. It would have made a profit were it not for a SFR2.7bn one-off hit on US tax reforms.

Under the new plans the executives stand to earn more in long-term bonuses, if they hit targets such as significantly increasing earnings.

Credit Suisse was forced to hastily ditch its plans to increase executive pay last year after shareholders voiced their opposition.

Ahead of this year's AGM, Credit Suisse has met with 27 top investors to try and explain the planned new pay increases in the hope of avoiding a repeat this year.

Credit Suisse argued the proposed changes placed more emphasis on hitting longer term goals - similar to pay structuring at UK banks - and the calculations had been made more transparent for investors.

Mr Thiam is under pressure to turn around the bank's fortunes, including from an activist investor - Swiss hedge fund RBR - which took a stake last year and is pressing for a break-up of the bank.

In 2017 the bank's wealth management business grew strongly, helping offset tough trading at its investment bank.
